So, I believe that the equation shown should have been
F=d(mv)

I see where you are coming from, and I understand your confusion; I was a bit thrown for a second at first as well. What he actually wrote was F = (m dot) times v , where m dot stands for rate of mass expulsion (kg/s) rather than just plain old m, which stands for mass (kg). With m dot, the units work out, because force in Newtons is (kg m/s^2) and m dot times v is (kg/s) times (m/s), so you end up with (kg m/s^2). :)

To help clarify what he meant by F=(m-dot)*v, think about the units.  m-dot is the rate of mass, as he mentioned, and would have the units kg/sec.  This describes the rate of mass ejected from the fire extinguisher.  To describe a force, this rate of mass must be multiplied by velocity, rather than acceleration, because 1 (kg/s)*(m/s) = 1 kg*(m/s^2) = 1 Newton.  The dot is a notation used to describe the derivative.  Hope this helps. :)
The m-dot as part of the formula he described was the "rate of mass".  It's the derivative of mass and its units would be kg/sec.  This would satisfy F=ma.  I hope that explains everything.

Derek mentions that 'Mdot' is rate of mass ejected by the extinguisher. Rate is another way of saying '...per unit time' (1/time).This means 'Mdot' can be represented as Mass/time. 
So 'F= (Mdot) x V' can also be written as 
F = (Mass/time) x V  ---->   F= (MxV)/  time
Remember 'Acceleration = V/time' so the equation above can be written as:- 
F = Mass x Acceleration

The Tsiolkovsky rocket equation is one of the most important equations in rocket physics. Most rockets loose their mass as they move so the equation becomes:

delta(V) = Ve * Ln(Mass1 / Mass2),

where Ve is the exhaust velocity relative to the rocket, Mass1 is the total mass of the rocket before launch, Mass2 is the final total mass of the rocket, and delta(V) is the total change of the rockets velocity. The Ln symbol means natural logarithm (log base e.)

If you accelerate too slowly, like a helicopter, you'll use most of your power generating thrust merely to cancel gravity. So the "first g of thrust" is all loss. However, if the rocket thrust generates 2g of force, 1g net actually goes to going up the gravitational potential (50% thrust wasted). If the thrust generates 3g of force, only 2g net actually goes to going up the gravitational potential (33% thrust wasted). If the thrust generates 5g, the thrust wasted is only 20% of total.

Simply put, there isn't just the force from the extinguisher.
There is also the static friction force from within the skateboard bearings, wheels, and the floor.
For something to accelerate, the object must have a positive net force. 
The extinguisher might exert a force of 5 N, but if the friction force (which always acts opposite of the direction of the other forces) is 5 N as well, then you won't accelerate.
Basically the force from the CO2 is not strong enough to overcome the friction force.

Derek "simplifies" the equation, but he explains what ṁ is. ṁ is the rate of change in mass at a position with respect to time, or its derivative. You could write it F = (m1-m2)/(t1-t2) * v. But v is the flow velocity of the propellant, so if you put the time interval under v instead, you get the rate of change in velocity over time: the acceleration. So the force applied is the mass ejected times the flow acceleration, or surprise surprise, F = ma.

If you are referring to the equation at about 1:30, listen carefully to what he says: it's not mass in the equation, it's mass over time (ie, kilograms per second).

F = ma is one of many force equations.
F = dm/dt v is another, (dm/dt is the same as what he calls m-dot in the video, and represents the rate of ejection of mass, and where v is the velocity of the ejected mass).

For example, if a 100N object ejected 20 kg of mass per second at an ejection rate of 5 m/s, the force exerted on the 100N object would be 100N - just enough to negate gravity (if the mass is ejected in the direction opposite to the direction of gravity, of course).

Mathematicians will hate this, but: for F=ma at an instantaneous point in time (dt), with the mass being ejected at that time (dm) and knowing a=dv/dt, force becomes F=(dm)(dv/dt). If you take this from an observing frame instead of one following the particles being ejected, you can effectively move the (dt), so that F=(dm/dt)(dv), but as the instantaneous velocity at ejection is the same for each case, F=(dm/dt)(v). Newton's second law is actually F = dp/dt. Force is the rate of change of momentum. Momentum (p) is mass * velocity (p = mv).
In most situations only the velocity changes over time - an acceleration - so you are left with F = ma (the rate of change of velocity is acceleration).
However, in this situation gas is ejected from the extinguisher at a constant rate/velocity of v causing the mass to change over time (the dot over the m means rate of change) so F = v*dm/dt (d/dt means change over time).
